content: welcome back not too long ago I ran a session with my players that took place
totally in a metropolis similar to Baldur's Gate and lots of plazas strewn
about it and in one of them was a bazaar this is one piece from that marketplace
and it went over really well obtain a typical tea light it needs to be no more
than one and a half inch in diameter and the body of it needs to be no more than
7/8 of an inch tall cut out a chipboard square one and a half inches to each
side locate dead center of the tile poke a hole and widen it so that the tea
lights flame will fit through apply hot glue and secure this square on
to the tea light apply a very thick coat of undiluted
white PVA glue to the square but not to the tea light flame flock with a few
pebbles and then sand let it dry overnight
apply a solid yellow base coat you may need to do two or three coats to get a
solid yellow depending on the quality of the paint you're using apply a medium
pressure dry brush in orange apply a light pressure dry rush in red
last apply a very light dusting of black to get a nice charcoal look
now let's build the structure get some dollar-store foam board which should be
3/16 of an inch thick from it measure out and cut to each of the following
designs for a total of four pieces apply a cobblestone texture to all four
of these pieces on one side only similar to what we did for the tavern tiles back
in episode 10 assemble the structure using hot glue
brush on a water and white glue mixture and let dry overnight to give it some
rigidity basse the structure in black insert the
tea light into the structure we need to secure it from the underside just pump
in a lot of hot glue in all four corners and it should spread out and do the job
let's prepare the roof use cereal box cardstock or anything of a similar
thickness cut out a rectangle of two-and-a-half inches by one in 7/8 of
an inch mark the center in the longer direction so that should be one and a
quarter inches and fold along that line hot glue the roof to the structure
again using cereal box cardstock cut a 1/2 inch wide strip chop that strip into
2-inch long segments take one of those segments and cut it
almost all the way through every quarter inch or so mix it up so it looks random
then chopped off just a sliver of these tongues that you've created to add
further randomness hot glue this to the bottom of the roof
you should have about 1/8 inch overhang in all three directions
repeat this and attach the next one such that there's about an eighth inch
overlap with the first one you get the idea
finish the whole roof this way four to each side
then to cap the top simply take one of those two inch segments and fold it
lengthwise then hot glue it on as shown basse the roof in black apply a medium
grey to your cobblestones with the brush at an extreme angle so as not to push
any painting to the cracks I left the interior black didn't bother
to a painted gray but do be sure that you hit all the edges of the four
windows for the shingles I simply apply Kuro fins wood paint scheme which we
covered back in episode 7 heavy dry brush of burnt umber healthy dry brush
of terracotta and a slightly lighter dry-brush of
honey brown finally get a lighter gray and pick out
a few random cobblestones on each side once again I'm using slate grey which I
love so much because it has a slight ever so slight hint of blue to it not
enough to really notice but enough to break the monotony of medium gray and
make the scenery pop I am why lock thank you for joining me
and I'll see you next time
